title: Financial Security
description: Assess how secure you feel about finances in your relationship

questions.text: I feel confident about our ability to handle financial challenges together.

therapeutic.rationale: Confidence in facing financial challenges together reflects trust in your partnership's resilience. This belief shapes how you'll approach difficult times.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different confidence levels may reflect different past experiences with financial stress. Discuss what would help the less confident partner feel more secure.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared confidence in handling challenges together is a relationship strength.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What gives you confidence—or doubt—about facing financial challenges as a couple?

questions.text: I trust my partner would be responsible if we faced financial difficulty.

therapeutic.rationale: Trust in your partner's responsibility during hard times is essential for security. This is often based on how they handle their own financial stresses now.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: A trust gap here needs exploration. What has the less-trusting partner observed that concerns them?
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual trust in each other's responsibility during difficulty creates a secure foundation.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your partner handle financial stress? What does that tell you about them?

questions.text: I don't worry that money issues would threaten our relationship.

therapeutic.rationale: Fear that money could threaten your relationship creates underlying anxiety. Confidence that your bond is stronger than financial stress allows you to face challenges as a team.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner worries more about money threatening the relationship, explore what drives that fear. Past experiences? Current observations?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared confidence that money won't threaten your bond creates security.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do you ever worry that money issues could damage your relationship? What drives that?

questions.text: I feel my partner and I have similar comfort levels with financial risk.

therapeutic.rationale: Risk tolerance affects everything from career moves to investments to lifestyle choices. Partners with very different risk profiles may struggle to make financial decisions together.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different risk tolerances aren't wrong—they need negotiation. The risk-averse partner's security needs and the risk-tolerant partner's growth needs both matter.
therapeutic.whenSame: Similar risk tolerance makes financial decision-making smoother.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Are you more financially cautious or adventurous? How does your partner compare?

questions.text: I believe we would support each other through a financial setback.

therapeutic.rationale: Belief in mutual support during setbacks is the essence of partnership. This confidence allows you to take appropriate risks knowing you're not alone.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doubts they'd be supported, explore what creates that doubt. Sometimes it's about how support is expressed rather than whether it exists.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual belief in supporting each other through setbacks is foundational security.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How would you want your partner to support you through a financial setback?
